channel.title: NYT > Technology
channel.copyright: Copyright 2017 The New York Times Company

item.title: State of the Art: How Technology Has Failed to Improve Your Airline Experience
item.media:description: United Airlines planes at San Francisco International Airport. Oscar Munoz, United’s chief executive, offered an apology and pledged to review the airline’s policies two days after a passenger was violently ejected from an overbooked flight.
item.description: Silicon Valley prides itself on its capacity to upend entrenched industries. But airlines have eluded tech disruption.
item.dc:creator: FARHAD MANJOO

item.title: A Chat With a Live Streamer Is Yours, for a Price
item.media:description: Andre Rebelo, live-streams his Grand Theft Auto 5 Mods game at home in Vancouver.
item.media:credit: Rafal Gerszak for The New York Times
item.description: Dedicated video streaming platforms like YouTube and Twitch are looking for ways to sweeten the deal for streamers so they produce more live content.
item.dc:creator: LAURA PARKER

item.title: New Tools Needed to Track Technology’s Impact on Jobs, Panel Says
item.media:description: Automation fears have stirred many fanciful visions of the future. An expert panel calls for new tools of analysis to help workers adapt.
item.description: The nation is “flying blind” into a new era of automation and artificial intelligence, the authors of a National Academies study warned.
item.dc:creator: STEVE LOHR

item.title: Tech We're Using: The Apps That Make Keeping Up With Soccer Easier
item.media:description: Rory Smith using his Apple iPad outside Stamford Bridge, home of Chelsea FC, in London.
item.media:credit: Tom Jamieson for The New York Times
item.description: The video-streaming apps Virgin Anywhere and Sky Sports Mobile TV are a boon for a soccer reporter, or a fan.
item.dc:creator: RORY SMITH

item.title: Bits: Tech Roundup: Paying Up to $500 to Chat With a Live Streamer
item.media:description: Andre Rebelo, live-streams his Grand Theft Auto 5 Mods game at home in Vancouver.
item.media:credit: Rafal Gerszak for The New York Times
item.description: YouTube’s Super Chat feature gives creators on the video site a new way to make money by charging audience members to have their comments highlighted during live streams.
item.dc:creator: PUI-WING TAM

item.title: Tech Tip: Send Some Sass With That Text Message
item.description: Apple’s own texting app for iOS 10 includes easy ways to liven up your interactions with other iMessage users.
item.dc:creator: J. D. BIERSDORFER

item.title: Uber Sees an Executive Exodus as It Faces Questions of Workplace Culture
item.media:description: Outside Uber’s headquarters in San Francisco.
item.description: In the last three months, several high-ranking managers have left the ride-hailing company. At least one has been openly critical about the way the company has been run.
item.dc:creator: MIKE ISAAC

item.title: Trilobites: A Lizard With Scales That Behave Like a Computer Simulation
item.media:description: An ocellated lizard. Their scales change from brown and white to black and green as they get older, and scientists say they appear to follow a pattern that is similar to a computer simulation.
item.description: Two mathematical models converge to illuminate the process through which an ocellated lizard’s scales repeatedly change color.
item.dc:creator: STEPH YIN

item.title: Bits: Tech Roundup: Advances for Airlines Aren’t Helping Customer Service
item.media:description: Online check-in, airport kiosks and apps allow airlines to serve customers with fewer and fewer workers.
item.description: Online check-ins, airport kiosks and the like are divorcing travelers from human workers, with the effort to drag a passenger off a United Airlines flight the culmination.
item.dc:creator: PUI-WING TAM

item.title: Tech Tip: Reading E-Books on a Bigger Screen
item.description: If you dislike reading on a phone or tablet, you can likely read your electronic books and magazines on your computer’s display instead.
item.dc:creator: J. D. BIERSDORFER

item.title: Burger King ‘O.K. Google’ Ad Doesn’t Seem O.K. With Google
item.description: The commercial was a novel but potentially invasive marketing tactic that came as more Americans use voice-activated devices.
item.dc:creator: SAPNA MAHESHWARI

item.title: Imagining the Retail Store of the Future
item.description: Will it have robots? No checkout counters? Virtual fitting rooms? Almost anything seems possible.
item.dc:creator: ELIZABETH PATON

item.title: Tesla’s Market Surge Has Even Fans Looking for Feet of Clay
item.media:description: Dennis Pascual with his Tesla Model S in the driveway of his home in Long Beach, Calif. An owner of two Teslas, he nonetheless said that the company’s stock was “a little pricey.”
item.media:credit: Andrew Cullen for The New York Times
item.description: Investors have been energized by the electric-car maker’s upbeat outlook for delivering its mass-market model. Now its chief, Elon Musk, must deliver.
item.dc:creator: NEAL E. BOUDETTE

item.title: Executive Who Steered Uber Through Scandals Joins Exodus
item.media:description: Rachel Whetstone, who is leaving her post as head of Uber’s policy and communications, in 2012.
item.description: Travis Kalanick, chief executive of the ride-sharing service, said Rachel Whetstone, the company’s head of policy and communications, was leaving of her own volition.
item.dc:creator: MIKE ISAAC

item.title: Border Officers Nearly Double Searches of Electronic Devices, U.S. Says
item.media:description: A Customs and Border Protection officer inspected a car entering the United States at the border at San Ysidro, Calif.
item.description: There were nearly 15,000 searches at border crossings and airports from October to March — up from 8,383 a year before, Customs and Border Protection said.
item.dc:creator: RON NIXON

item.title: Bits: Tech Roundup: The Vast Criminal Enterprise Lurking Behind Spam Emails
item.description: The Department of Justice accused a Russian of being a mastermind behind an enormous spam email operation that officials said drained people’s bank accounts.
item.dc:creator: PUI-WING TAM

item.title: Yahoo Is Sued Over $17 Million Fund for Chinese Dissidents
item.media:description: Harry Wu in 2011. A lawsuit against Yahoo says that Mr. Wu, who died last year, misspent money set aside for a foundation that Yahoo created to aid Chinese dissidents.
item.description: Activists said the company failed to properly oversee the fund it created to help Chinese writers, democracy advocates and human rights lawyers persecuted for standing up to the country’s government.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Tech Tip: A Hangout for Old Desktop Notifications
item.description: If the pop-up alerts that bring you news and information from your Mac’s apps disappear before you can read them, check the Notifications Center.
item.dc:creator: J. D. BIERSDORFER

item.title: Deal by Chinese Tech Company LeEco for Vizio Dies
item.media:description: LeEco, which has investments in products from telephones to cars, said it would not buy the American television maker Vizio.
item.description: The ambitious conglomerate, which said unspecified regulatory problems had derailed the American TV acquisition, grew quickly but its cash has dwindled.
item.dc:creator: RYAN McMORROW

item.title: Toshiba Casts Doubt on Its Ability to Stay in Business
item.media:description: One of the better-known suitors for Toshiba’s chip unit is Hon Hai Precision Industry, also known as Foxconn.
item.description: Struggling after a disastrous foray into nuclear power, the company hopes a sale of part of its microchip business, its crown jewel, could alleviate uncertainty.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE and PAUL MOZUR

item.title: First Words: New Technology Is Built on a ‘Stack.’ Is That the Best Way to Understand Everything Else, Too?
item.description: People from nutrition geeks to philosophers are using a metaphor from software to describe the world.
item.dc:creator: JOHN HERRMAN

item.title: That Fingerprint Sensor on Your Phone Is Not as Safe as You Think
item.media:description: Nasir Memon, a professor of computer science and engineering at New York University, said his research into master fingerprints suggested that the security on iPhones and Android phones could be easily cracked.
item.media:credit: Roger Kisby for The New York Times
item.description: New research suggests that the fingerprint security features on iPhones and Android devices can be easily fooled by so-called MasterPrint fakes.
item.dc:creator: VINDU GOEL

item.title: U.S. Accuses Russian Email Spammer of Vast Network of Fraud
item.media:description: President Trump boarded Air Force One on Sunday. The Justice Department’s accusations against a Russian email spammer are sure to raise tensions when Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson visits Moscow this week.
item.description: Peter Levashov, 36, arrested on vacation in Spain, is charged with wire fraud and unauthorized interception of electronic communications.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL SCHWIRTZ

item.title: Bits: Tech Roundup: Canada Spends to Keep A.I. Experts Home
item.media:description: The Mars Discovery District in Toronto is one of the world’s largest innovation hubs. After years of losing its artificial intelligence scientists and start-ups to Silicon Valley, Canada is focusing on keeping its A.I. leaders in the country.
item.media:credit: Aaron Vincent Elkaim for The New York Times
item.description: Canadian researchers have played a major role in developing artificial intelligence. Now the government is helping to create research centers to retain them.
item.dc:creator: PUI-WING TAM

item.title: Tech Tip: Yes, Another Windows 10 Update Is Here
item.description: Microsoft is now rolling out the Windows 10 Creators Update, a new version of its flagship operating system.
item.dc:creator: J. D. BIERSDORFER

item.title: Tesla Hits a New Milestone, Passing G.M. in Valuation
item.media:description: The Tesla Model S sedan at a showroom in San Francisco. Investors are betting that the company has room to grow as the world’s appetite for electric vehicles expands.
item.description: After passing Ford Motor a week ago, the electric car company edged past General Motors in early trading, with a market capitalization of $50.9 billion.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Spain Arrests Russian Thought to Be Kingpin of Computer Spam
item.description: Western cybersecurity researchers have identified the man being held, Peter Levashov, as the spammer known as Peter Severa, though some doubt he is the same person.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Canada Tries to Turn Its A.I. Ideas Into Dollars
item.media:description: The Mars Discovery District in Toronto is one of the world’s largest innovation hubs. After years of losing its artificial intelligence scientists and start-ups to Silicon Valley, Canada is focusing on keeping its A.I. leaders in the country.
item.media:credit: Aaron Vincent Elkaim for The New York Times
item.description: Today’s striking advances in artificial intelligence owe a lot to research in Canada over the years. But the country has so far failed to cash in.
item.dc:creator: STEVE LOHR

item.title: Hacking Attack Woke Up Dallas With Emergency Sirens, Officials Say
item.media:description: Warning sirens in Dallas, meant to alert the public to emergencies like severe weather, started sounding around 11:40 p.m. Friday, and were not shut off until 1:20 a.m.
item.media:credit: Rex C. Curry for The New York Times
item.description: All 156 of the city’s sirens, which are meant to alert severe weather or other emergencies, sounded into the early hours of Saturday morning.
item.dc:creator: ELI ROSENBERG and MAYA SALAM

item.title: Bits: Farhad’s and Mike’s Week in Tech: Why We’ll Miss Walt Mossberg
item.media:description: Veteran tech journalists Walt Mossberg, left, and Kara Swisher with Jim Bankoff, chief executive of Vox.
item.media:credit: Kendrick Brinson for The New York Times
item.description: Twitter fights the government, Google fights Uber, and we fight back tears over a tech columnist’s retirement.
item.dc:creator: FARHAD MANJOO and MIKE ISAAC

item.title: When Solar Panels Became Job Killers
item.media:description: Workers for Wuhan Guangsheng Photovoltaic Company installing solar panels on a roof in Wuhan, China. China is home to two-thirds of the world’s solar-production capacity, and buys half of the world’s new solar panels.
item.media:credit: Giulia Marchi for The New York Times
item.description: A policy change in China hurt workers in Ohio, revealing the trade challenges facing President Trump.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: Applied Science: Damaging Your Phone, Accidentally on Purpose
item.description: Consumers are more likely to be careless with products when they know an upgrade is available, research has found.
item.dc:creator: PHYLLIS KORKKI

item.title: Preoccupations: I’m Not Texting. I’m Taking Notes.
item.description: Generations are different, and for digital natives, what looks like wasting time may actually be doing research or something else productive.
item.dc:creator: JONAH STILLMAN

item.title: Bits: Tech Roundup: The U.S. Blinks in Standoff With Twitter
item.media:description: The Twitter app. The social media company sued the government after receiving a summons seeking information about who was behind an anonymous account critical of the Trump administration.
item.description: The company sued after received a summons to disclose the user behind an account critical of President Trump that claimed to have ties to a government agency. A day later the government withdrew the summons.
item.dc:creator: JIM KERSTETTER

item.title: U.S. Blinks in Clash With Twitter; Drops Order to Unmask Anti-Trump Account
item.media:description: The Twitter app. The social media company sued the government after receiving a summons seeking information about who was behind an anonymous account critical of the Trump administration.
item.description: A day after Twitter sued to block a summons seeking information about who was behind an anonymous account, the federal government withdrew the summons.
item.dc:creator: MIKE ISAAC

item.title: Tech Tip: An Alternate Plan in Case of a 911 Failure
item.description: Mobile carriers have had occasional trouble routing emergency calls to 911 centers, but you can plan ahead for a possible service disruption.
item.dc:creator: J. D. BIERSDORFER

item.title: Uber Denies It Is Using Stolen Waymo Technology
item.media:description: An Uber autonomous car driving in San Francisco earlier this year. The lidar sensors on the car’s roof are at the center of a legal dispute between Uber and Waymo.
item.description: The ride-hailing service said it started developing its own self-driving car systems before hiring an ex-Google employee accused of the theft.
item.dc:creator: DAISUKE WAKABAYASHI and MIKE ISAAC

item.title: Does Uber Really Prevent Drunken Driving? It Depends on the Study
item.media:description: Some studies say Uber ride-hailing services have reduced drunken driving accidents, but researchers say more data is needed.
item.media:credit: Sam Hodgson for The New York Times
item.description: The ride-hailing company says its services can prevent alcohol-related car accidents, and some researchers agree — but not all.
item.dc:creator: JACEY FORTIN
